Award.AwardTitle: UNS:Modeling Bulk Composition Dependent Alloy Surface Properties Under Reaction Conditions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Kitchin, 1506770
Alloy catalysts, consisting of mixtures of two or more metals, are widely used in commercial applications to promote reactions more effectively than possible with a single metal. However, in designing new catalysts, it is difficult to predict which combinations of two or more metals will be the most effective for a given reaction, especially because the active surface sites in gas-solid catalytic reactions typically are different in structure and composition than those of the bulk alloy. This work will develop an improved model for predicting the catalytic reactivity of alloy catalysts under actual working conditions, thereby enabling the discovery of new and improved alloy catalysts without the need for costly and time-consuming synthesis and testing of large arrays of potential metal combinations.

The work addresses two major factors that hinder direct correlation of bulk alloy composition with catalytic reactivity: surface segregation and adsorbate-induced changes in surface composition. Specifically, the novel aspect of the study is to combine a surface site distribution function (where the reactivity of each site is calculated by density functional theory) with a surface segregation model (that includes adsorbate-induced effects) to produce a statistically weighted average property of the alloy surface. The new approach will be applied to the design of optimized Ag-Pd alloys for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene in the presence of ethylene - a commercially important reaction.

The theoretical methods developed in this study will have broad impact to the catalysis industry by enabling more efficient design of catalysts than simple trial-and-error methods, and by producing catalysts that are more active, selective, and energy-efficient than catalysts currently in use. In addition, the researchers will make their methods openly available to the catalysis community, both as a research tool and as an educational tool.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mixtures of metals, called alloys, are often used to speed up chemical reactions because the mixture is better than the pure component metals. It is challenging to understand how alloys are better than pure metals because the reactions depend on the composition of the alloy at the surface, which is often different than that of the bulk due to segregation. Simulation methods based on quantum chemical calculations have led to substantial understanding of how the reactions depend on surface composition, but they are too expensive to use to make accurate predictions of the surface composition under reaction conditions.


In this project we developed an approach to use machine learning to build models based on quantum chemical calculations that are as accurate as those expensive calculations, but that are cheap to compute. With these cheap models we showed that we can accurately simulate the surface composition of an alloy across the alloy composition space. For a specific example of an Au-Pd alloy, we showed that this approach accurately predicted the surface composition for bulk alloy compositions from 10-90% Au, in excellent agreement with experimental results. We also showed that this machine learning approach can be used to develop models for reactive processes at metal surfaces, e.g. metal atom diffusion or dissociative oxygen adsorption and surface oxidation. This is an important advance in simulating reactions at surfaces because it allows one to create accurate but cheap models that are not limited by the expense of quantum chemical calculations. The approach developed in this work is general, and can be applied more broadly in simulating catalytic environments and materials.


This project also contributed to the development of an open-source scientific publishing tool that facilitates data sharing and reproducibility. This tool enables the integration of narrative text, bibliographic citations, equations, figures, tables, multifunctional hyperlinks, code, data and results into an executable, interactive document. These documents can be converted to a variety of output formats, including PDF, LaTeX, HTML, and Jupyter notebooks. By integrating all of these components into one document, one has a nearly complete record of what they were trying to do, how they did it, and how they interpreted the results. The documents are in plain text, making it easy to share them, and for others to reproduce or build on the work in them. This tool is useful broadly in scientific and technical documentation, including the production of educational materials where interactive documents can be used with code and data.
